questions.text: Which of the following images shows the typical features of a plasma cell in a histopathological examination (HPE) of bone marrow?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A

Explanation:
 

 

HPE image

Explanation

(Option A)

Plasma cell
  • Ovoid cells with deep blue cytoplasm.
  • Pale perinuclear area (halo)/hoff made of Golgi apparatus (help in Ab production, which are proteins).
  • Eccentric Nucleus with coarse chromatin arranged in a clock face (cartwheel) pattern.

(Option B)

Osteoblast

 

Eccentric nucleus with a pale area away from the nucleus containing the Golgi apparatus (para-nuclear halo/hoff).

(Option C)

Fibroblast

 
  • Spindle-shaped cells with round nucleus.
  • Cells and their extracellular matrix products (fibres and amorphous ground substance) maintain the structural integrity of connective tissues and play key roles in healing processes.

(Option D)

Mast Cell

 
  • Oval-shaped with dense, granular cytoplasm and a central, single nucleus.
  • Play a key role in Type 1 hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with 6 months of persistent fatigue, lower back pain and recurrent infections. Laboratory tests show hypercalcemia, elevated creatinine, and normocytic anemia. Serum protein electrophoresis indicates a monoclonal spike. Bone marrow biopsy shows atypical plasma cells with eccentric nuclei and perinuclear halos, as shown in the image below. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Trisomy 21

Explanation:

The patient most likely has Multiple myeloma (MM), a plasma cell neoplasm associated with hypercalcemia, renal failure, anaemia, lytic bone lesions (CRAB features) and immune abnormalities. Trisomy 21 is associated with Down’s syndrome and not multiple myeloma.

  • It is seen in patients 60-70 years of age.
  • There are 3 main cytogenetic abnormalities seen in MM.
    • Deletion of chromosome 13q (also seen in CLL) (Option A)
    • Translocation t (11;14) (also seen in mantle cell lymphoma) (Option B)
    • Deletion of chromosome 17p (TP53) (Option D)
    • IL-6 essential for plasma cell growth, elevated IL-6 linked to poor prognosis.

 

Antibodies in Multiple Myeloma:

Monoclonal Immunoglobulins

Free Light Chains
  • IgG: Most common (55% of patients).
  • IgA: Seen in 25% of cases.
  • IgM, IgD, IgE: Less common.
  • Often produced in excess, called Bence Jones proteins.
  • Can cause myeloma kidney (renal disease).

 

Pathogenesis of Multiple Myeloma:

 

  • Renal failure in multiple myeloma is usually higher in IgD subtype.
  • Increased plasma cells activate MiP1α, resulting in
    • Increased osteoclastic activity leads to bone resorption hypercalcemia and lytic punched-out lesions.
    • Decreased osteoblastic activity (Normal or ↓ ALP levels)

Multiple Punched-out Osteolytic Lesions on the Lateral Skull Radiograph in a patient with Multiple Myeloma

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with complaints of persistent bone pain, particularly in his lower back and ribs, along with fatigue and recurrent infections over the past few months. Further workup demonstrates Bence Jones proteinuria. What temperature does it precipitate at?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 60°C

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and Bence Jones proteinuria are consistent with Multiple myeloma
  • Multiple myeloma cells produce excess free light chains, either alongside complete immunoglobulins or independently.
  • Due to their small size, free light chains (Bence Jones proteins) can pass through the glomeruli of the kidneys and appear in urine. This is a diagnostic marker for multiple myeloma.

Bence Jones Proteinuria: The presence of Bence Jones proteins in urine contributes to myeloma kidney, a form of renal damage.

  • These light chains exert toxic effects on renal tubular epithelial cells, leading to renal impairment.
  • It is a kappa or lambda light chain immunoglobulin that precipitates in the urine at 40-60°C. When boiling, it disappears and reappears when cooling.
  • Urine and serum electrophoresis show a characteristic M spike due to increased levels of monoclonal IgG.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with bone pain, recurrent infections, elevated serum calcium levels, renal dysfunction, and anaemia. Laboratory tests reveal an M spike on serum protein electrophoresis and the presence of Bence Jones proteins in the urine. Based on this presentation, which of the following is not a criterion for a myeloma-defining event in the diagnostic criteria for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bence jones proteinuria

Explanation:

The clinical scenario is consistent with Multiple myeloma in which Bence jones proteinuria is not a diagnostic criterion for a myeloma-defining event according to the current diagnostic criteria for the condition

Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Myeloma:
  • ≥10% clonal bone marrow plasma cells (or) a biopsy-proven bony or extra medullary plasmacytoma        

                        +  (PLUS)

  • Evidence of one or more multiple myeloma defining events (MDE): (CRAB features)
    • HyperCalcemia (S.Ca2+ >11g/dl)  (Option A)
    • Renal failure (S. Creatinine >2mg/dl) (Option C)
    • Anaemia (Hb <10gm) (Option B)
    • Lytic Bone lesions are attributable to the plasma cell disorder.

                 (OR)

  • One or more biomarkers of malignancy (SLIM criteria)
    • Bone marrow clonal plasmacytosis ≥60% (Sixty per cent)
    • Serum involved/uninvolved free Light chain (FLC) ratio ≥ 100 (provided involved FLC is ≥100 mg/L)
    • >1 focal lesion on MRI.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman is being evaluated for monoclonal gammopathy. Bone marrow examination showed abnormal proliferation of plasma cells with evidence of certain microscopic features. Match the following structures with corresponding histopathological images regarding this condition.



 


	
		
			
			1. Flame Cell
			
			
			a) 

			
			
		
		
			
			2. Mott cell
			
			
			b) 

			
			
		
		
			
			3. Russel bodies
			
			
			c) 

			
			
		
		
			
			4. Dutcher bodies
			
			
			d)
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 1-d; 2-c; 3-a; 4-b

Explanation:

The patient most likely has multiple myeloma, a plasma cell neoplasm, and can present with characteristic histopathological features such as:

INCLUSION BODIES SEEN IN MULTIPLE MYELOMA

Russel bodies

 
  • Location: Intracytoplasmic
  • Composition:
  • Eosinophilic
  • Round
  • Dilated endoplasmic reticulum cisternae filled with condensed immunoglobulin.

.

Dutcher bodies

 
  • Location: Intranuclear.
  • Composition: Globular inclusions containing accumulated immunoglobulin.

PLASMA CELL VARIANTS IN MULTIPLE MYELOMA

Mott cells

 
  • Contain Grape-like cytoplasmic droplets.
  • Composition: Inclusion bodies, fibrils, crystalline rods, and globules.

 

Flame cells

 
  • Appearance: Fiery red cytoplasm.
  • Cause: High concentration of immunoglobulin as bright red granules within the cytoplasm.
  • Often seen in IgA subtype myeloma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with fatigue, bone pain, and recurrent infections. Laboratory tests show elevated IL-6 and beta-2 microglobulin levels, while imaging reveals multiple lytic bone lesions. Bone marrow biopsy showed a high percentage of plasma cells, and cytogenetic analysis revealed a deletion of chromosome 17p. Flow cytometry is performed to distinguish abnormal plasma cells from normal ones in this patient. Which marker commonly shows increased expression on plasma cells in multiple myeloma, aiding in this differentiation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CD56

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario is consistent with Multiple myeloma with poor prognosis.
  • CD56 is a marker commonly overexpressed on plasma cells in multiple myeloma, and it helps to differentiate malignant cells from normal plasma cells.

 

Prognostic factors of Multiple myeloma

  • Good prognosis: t(11;14) chromosomal abnormality is associated with a better prognosis compared to high-risk cytogenetic features like t(4;14) and del(17p)
  • Poor prognosis:
    • ↑ Beta-2 Microglobulin Level;
    • ↑ IL-6;
    • ↑ Lactate Dehydrogenase;
    • High serum to free light chain levels
    • Deletions of chromosome 17p (TP53)

CD19 (Option A): It is a pan-B cell marker, absent on malignant plasma cells in multiple myeloma but may be expressed on normal plasma cells.

 

CD 38 (Option B):

  • CD38 is a marker highly expressed on plasma cells, both normal and malignant.
  • High levels of CD38 are a characteristic feature of multiple myeloma plasma cells. However, CD38 is also found on other cells, so it is combined with other markers like CD138 to identify malignant plasma cells specifically.

 

CD 117 (Option D):

  • CD117, or c-kit, is a receptor tyrosine kinase that is sometimes expressed on hematopoietic stem cells and progenitor cells.
  • CD117 can be expressed in multiple myeloma and is associated with a poorer prognosis. However, its presence is less common than CD56 in multiple myeloma cells. When positive, it can indicate a more aggressive disease course.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with fatigue, bone pain, and recurrent infections. Laboratory tests reveal hypercalcemia and increased beta-2 microglobulin; imaging shows multiple lytic bone lesions. Which biochemical test is most commonly used to assess renal function and evaluate kidney damage in patients with multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Serum creatinine levels

 

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with multiple myeloma features in which renal involvement is common due to factors like hypercalcemia and the deposition of monoclonal light chains in the renal tubules (light chain cast nephropathy).
  • Serum creatinine levels are the most commonly used biochemical test to assess renal function and detect kidney damage.

 

Biochemical tests useful in the diagnosis of Multiple Myeloma

  1. Serum Protein Electrophoresis (SPEP): Detects and measures M-proteins in blood, aiding in multiple myeloma diagnosis and monitoring. But does not help in assessing kidney damage. (Option A)
  2. Urine Protein Electrophoresis (UPEP): Identifies Bence Jones proteins in urine, supporting multiple myeloma diagnosis. (Option D)
  3. Serum Free Light Chain Assay: Measures free kappa and lambda light chains, useful for diagnosis and treatment monitoring.
  4. Serum creatinine: Elevated levels indicate renal impairment.
  5. Serum calcium: Commonly elevated due to bone resorption. But does not assess renal function (Option C)
  6. CBC: Look for anaemia, leukopenia, or thrombocytopenia.
  7. Albumin to globulin ratio - reversed
  8. Serum Beta 2 microglobulin - Increased

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a routine health check-up is found to have a serum M protein level of 3.5 g/dL and plasma cells making up 25% of the marrow cellularity. He reports no bone pain, normal kidney function, normal calcium levels, and no lytic bone lesions on imaging. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Smouldering Myeloma

Explanation:

  • The clinical findings suggest Smouldering Myeloma. It is a precursor condition to multiple myeloma, lying between Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Significance (MGUS) and symptomatic multiple myeloma.
  • It is characterised by the presence of monoclonal protein in the absence of end-organ damage, with bone marrow plasma cell infiltration of ≥10% and <30% without myeloma-defining events.

Plasma cell leukemia (Option B) is a rare and aggressive form of multiple myeloma associated with myc gene mutations.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with blurred vision, dizziness, and epistaxis. Physical examination reveals engorged retinal veins and signs of haemorrhage. Laboratory tests show an elevated serum viscosity. Serum protein electrophoresis reveals a monoclonal IgM spike. What is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Waldenstrom’s Macroglobulinemia

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation suggests Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia, a lymphoproliferative disorder characterised by the presence of monoclonal IgM antibodies.

 

Waldenström Macroglobulinemia (WM):

  • Increased association with Lymphoplasmacytic Lymphoma (LPL)
  • It is also associated with MYD 88 mutation.
  • Patients may present with symptoms of hyperviscosity syndrome, such as blurred vision, dizziness, and bleeding tendencies.
  • Diagnosis: monoclonal IgM gammopathy on serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) or immunofixation electrophoresis (IFE)

 

Hyperviscosity Syndrome:

  • Caused by high levels of IgM increasing blood viscosity.
  • Visual Impairment: Sluggish blood flow and venous congestion in the retinal veins cause visual disturbances, retinal haemorrhages, and exudates.
  • Neurological Issues: Reduced brain blood flow leads to headaches, dizziness, deafness, and stupor.
  • Bleeding: Macroglobulins form complexes with clotting factors and interfere with platelet function, increasing bleeding risk.
  • Cryoglobulinemia: Macroglobulins precipitate at low temperatures, causing Raynaud phenomenon and cold urticaria.
  • Treatment: Observation, immunotherapy, chemotherapy, and plasmapheresis for hyperviscosity symptoms.

Multiple Myeloma (Option A): Multiple myeloma is characterised by the presence of monoclonal IgG or IgA antibodies, not IgM.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (Option B): CLL is a B-cell malignancy characterised by the accumulation of monoclonal B lymphocytes and not IgM antibodies.

IgA Myeloma (Option C): A subtype of multiple myeloma that primarily produces monoclonal IgA. While it can cause hyperviscosity syndrome, it is not characterised by an IgM spike.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with recurrent infections and fatigue. Palatal edema is noted. Laboratory tests show hypogammaglobulinemia and serum protein electrophoresis reveals an absence of normal immunoglobulins but a monoclonal spike in the gamma region. Bone marrow biopsy reveals large lymphoid cells with intracytoplasmic inclusions. Which type of heavy chain disease is most likely causing the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Gamma Heavy Chain Disease

 

Explanation: The clinical scenario is consistent with Gamma heavy chain disease (Franklin’s Disease).

 

  • Heavy-chain diseases are rare monoclonal gammopathies characterized by the production and secretion of free heavy-chain fragments.
  • These diseases can be associated with various disorders, including:
    • Lymphoplasmacytic Lymphoma
    • Small Bowel Marginal Zone Lymphoma

Gamma heavy chain disease (Franklin's disease): (Option B)

  • Present with systemic symptoms & sometimes palatal and uvular swelling.
  • Involves the production of abnormal monoclonal gamma heavy chains without associated light chains, resulting in hypogammaglobulinemia and recurrent infections.
  • Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) reveals a monoclonal spike in the gamma region.

 

Alpha heavy chain disease (Seligmann's Disease) (Option A): The most common type. Often presents as a gastrointestinal immunoproliferative small intestinal disease (IPSID).

 

Mu heavy chain disease (Option C): A very rare subtype that resembles chronic lymphocytic leukaemia/small lymphocytic leukaemia

 

Delta heavy chain disease (Option D): Extremely rare subtype.
